{"step_by_step_thinking": "Pregnancy-induced hypertension, also known as gestational hypertension, can lead to several complications. Renal failure, pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome are all potential complications of pregnancy-induced hypertension. Renal failure can occur due to the increased pressure on the kidneys. Pre-eclampsia is a severe form of hypertension that can occur during pregnancy, and HELLP syndrome is a life-threatening pregnancy complication usually considered to be a variant of preeclampsia. On the other hand, fetal macrosomia, which is a condition where a baby is significantly larger than average, is more commonly associated with gestational diabetes rather than hypertension.", "answer_choice": "D. Fetal macrosomia"}
